bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, October 27, 1879

div1.p: Reed hopes his son remembers him. Reed learns he will not have an assignment to Fort Thomas. He notes that the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad is moving closer to Fort Apache. He writes about finances and military personnel.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, October 27, 1879
div1.p:
Two mighty
“feet” letters by yesterday's mail-
one dated Oct. 5 & the other Octr 10th.
Papa is much obliged to his dar-
-ling wifie for writing him
two letters every week, which is
more by half than “hubby” does,
and which shows how much
she thinks of her ugly old Ari-
-zona mantee. Love Papa's
son's little heart!, papa is much
obliged to him, too, for sending
him some pretty rose leaves-
To think that papa's darling
Laurie has had these petals
in his own darling “ittle”
hands makes them very dear
to papa's heart! Do you think,
Emilie darling, that he appre-
-ciates the fact that his papa
is away from him? or does he
mistake any gentleman for his
“daddie” & call him so? I wonder
whether he would not know
me, if I should come into the
room? I really believe he
would- I am certain that he
would know me, if I should
recall to his memory a few
old apache expressions; such
as “ditn't, ditn't, day”, and “bad
daddies”- I had a letter from
Pa, dated Octr 9th, and he mentions
his brightness,- says he thinks he
is as smart as any child he
ever saw, and that he begins
to talk considerably- He
seems to think a great deal
of him, and never fails to mention
both of them you in his letters.
You can tell Dr John, for me,
that Lawrence derives his
brightness from his mother,
and his sweet disposition too-
Now ain't we about even, lov-
ie? Bless your sweet life and
heart! You know every body says
that he is just like his mother!
Of course, lovie, dear, it must
be remembered that he first
sniffed the oxygen, so to speak,
in the heart of the “sierra blan-
cas”, and this fact must have
something to do with his bright-
-ness; besides, lovie, you must
not forget that the five quarts
of milk which he daily drank,
was extracted from a very
sensible cow; or as Jimmie
“spin up the Creek” would
say, a “noble animal”! All
these things must be taken
into consideration; and last
and not least, that his papa
(and mama, too) started him in
“the way that he should go”-
Bless his sweet, innocent,
life, papa prays every day
that his health & life may
be spared, to be a joy &
comfort to mama & papa!
Talk to him very often about
me, my precious wifie, and
don't let him forget his papa.
Make him guide the pencil
very often in writing to his
dear “daddie”, and kiss him many
times every day for papa!
I also had a letter, yesterday,
from Colonel Biddle- You
remember that he promised
to have me ordered to Thomas.
He writes that he did every
thing he could, but that the
Medical Director replied,
“Biddle, I won't do it! Apa-
che is too large & important
a Post for a contract Doctor,
and I can't accommodate you”.
Page 5. So you perceive, my
precious darling, that my
chances of going to Thomas are
not very favorable. Of course,
as far as Comfort is concerned
there is no comparison be-
-tween the two Posts. There are
no quarters at Thomas, and
plenty of dust & heat to be
endured. I wanted to go,
as my precious Emilie knows,
in order to be able to com-
-municate more often with
her and for no other reason.
It would have been very
convenient, when I am or-
-dered out, next year, but I
assure, my darling wifie,
that when I am once re-
-lieved, I won't waste
much time, on the road, in
hastening to my pretty, sweet
wifie and boy! The Atchison
Santa Fe and Topeka R. Road
will be at Albuquerque
(a town situated “hard by” the
Rio Grande, a river which is
very hard to cross, when you
have to wait three hours
for a few thick headed, lazy
Mexicans to make up their
minds! Dost remember, lovie?)
by the 1st of January, and by the
time I am ordered out, it may
be much nearer Apache.
Mantee won't be on the way
more than 12 or 14 days, at the
outside! Do you hear that
lovie? Won't that be perfectly
splendid? Hesche, Enchaw!
You ought to see the heap of
pretties I got by yesterday's
mail, lovie! Some nice “gents
balbriggan” (“I want to know”,)
and I cant now remove the
“Clothes-line” from my heel-
also four (4) good shirts,
which came to hand, just
in time, as my others were
beginning to give out at the
button-holes in the neck-band;
otherwise they haven't got
a “brack” in them. I got, be-
-sides, lovie, a pretty army
cap. The first I received,
about a month ago, was
too small and I had to re-
turn it. This one fits me ex-
-actly, and of course, is very
becoming! Ahem! “Boodigs”!
I have now got collars,
shirts & socks - and a nice,
new pair of full-dress pants
which Krobrisch,(Captain
Hentig's Co. Tailor,) made for
me, out of cloth which I
got from A.T. Stewarts- and
all of which are paid for
thank goodness - as well
as my military cap too.
I have a bill of $5.00, for shoul-
-der straps & buttons to pay,
and I shall send the money
by this mail- Besides, I have
sent to Mr Stewarts for 2 yds
of nice, dark-blue, broad-cloth
with which to have a good
blouse made. I think the
cloth and making will cost about
$18- I am done buying quar-
-termaster's blue cloth, as
it wears out so quick & be-
-comes so easily soiled that
it is a waste of money in
the long run. The above are
all the outside expenses I
will have during the remain-
der of the year- certainly $25
will cover every thing. Now,
as my little wifie wanted
to know about how much we
could save, I will enter into
particulars a little bit. In the
first place, darling, you say
(Page 9.) that you have enough
to pay your way back to Nor-
folk, and that Mr Vaughan has
$60.00 of your money- well that
is very good, for my darling wifie.
The check of $50.00 which husband
sent you on the 8th of Octr &
which you have already re-
-ceived by this time, will bring
your money up to $110.00 when
you get to Norfolk during
the latter part of November.
Now as you have a nice new dress
& hat to buy for your darling self & some things for
our little boy, I don't suppose
my darling would have more
than $25.00 left on, say, Decem-
ber 1st. Well, suppose, lovie,
for argument's sake, we will
take it for granted that you
have $25.00 on Decr 1st; then
if husband should send you
a check for $50.00 more, wouldn't
that take you through the year?
you understand, my precious
wifie, that I am only supposing
a case - and my darling little
wifie is such an apt hand
at paper & pencil and making
up accounts generally,(love
her darling heart!) that I know
she will grab her paper and
pencil and go to figuring at
once. Now, husband doesn't
forget that he said, in the
letter, enclosing the $50 check,
that he was going to send you
$75.00 more for the rest of the
year, and he will do so, if you
need it; but since mother
is so anxious to add to our
little sum, something more
this year, I have made the
above proposition- The idea
of husband using thinner
paper & thus saving on pos-
tage stamps was too sweet
for any purpose; & husband
owes his wifie 42 kisses and
a half for that suggestion!
Now to return to the subject;
if $50.00 more will pay mama's
& son's expenses till Jan. 1st, then
papa can save, at least, $175.00
or probably $200 during the re-
-mainder of this year. If Mama
will only bear in mind that
papa's expenses will be, every
month that papa remains
in Arizona, about $50.00, and
if she keeps an account of her
monthly expenses, she will know
about what we can save
every month, next year-
Going upon the basis of the
amount mentioned above be-
ing sufficient to carry you
through the year, then ac-
-cording to my figures, lovie
dear, your expenses & papa's
boy's, during the 8 months, from
May 1st to Jan. 1st will have
been about $560.00, or at the
rate of $70.00 a month. Now,
my precious wifie, husband
is perfectly satisfied with that
showing, and he thinks mother, dear,
has done well to keep her ex-
penses down to that amount.
Of course, my precious wifie,
next year, you will not pay
board all the time, and your
expenses will be less. We will
have to economize and save some-
-thing, each month, in order
to buy our furniture for
our new home and lots of other
things. But I have no fear
on that point, as I know my
precious wifie is just as anx-
-ious to save & have a nice,
pretty home, and nice pretty things
in it, as mantee is - and she will
have a heap of “pretties,” won't you, lovie?
(Page 13.) Tuesday Morning Octr 28th 79.
Just to think, precious wifie, that
October is almost gone, & Novem-
ber nearly here! One more month
gone certainly, lovie, and husband
is one month nearer his little
wifie & son! Oh! how I wish
Jan. 1st 1880 was here, for then I
could begin to look forward
to seeing my wife & boy, during
the year certainly. Time passes
rapidly, my precious wife, but
not near so fast, as it did when
precious Mamma & son were at
Apache, and not nearly so fast as
I know it must pass with
you, lovie. You have so many
things to engage your attention;
and so many little trips & visits
here and there, that the month
must go by right quickly.
At any rate, husband trusts
that time does not hang heavy
on his darling's hands. “Boodigs”!
Mantee can't help from feeling
lonely sometimes, for he has to
sit in his room all alone,
& not a soul to talk to- But
he does not complain of his
fate, but awaits the coming
days hopefully, trustfully-
Dr McPherson has not yet
returned. I think though that
he will be back at apache
within three weeks. Captain
Hentig's company does not
go to Thomas after all- Cap't.
Foulk's company goes from
Thomas to Grant, and Captain
Tupper's Co. comes from Grant
to Thomas. Captain McGowan
goes to Fort Rucker and the
company there of the 12th Inf
comes to apache. This brings
Lt. Halloran & wife & Lt.
Smith and wife- The former
lady said to be a “Bridget”
of the “purest ray serene;” and
the last named lady, Mrs. Smith
is a blooming bride, from
somewhere in New York State.
As the “Duchess” & “Countess” re-
-main at apache, this will give
us six (6) ladies. I tell Mrs.
Hentig that the writer will
be the liveliest ever known
at Apache; in fact, one con-
-tinual season of jollity
and “flow of soul”, as it were.
But the “Duchess” doubts my
statement very much- She thinks
there won't be life enough
in the garrison to get up
a pick nick even! It's very
true that, at present, you
would not know that there
was a lady in the garrison.
For a week at a time you
never see one out of doors,
& this, too, while we are hav-
ing the most charming wea-
ther. I never experienced more
beautiful weather than we
have had, for the last four
or five days, and how they can
stick in the house & glue
themselves to chair-bottoms
so firmly, I can't see. If both
of them were not cut out
for princesses or queens,
I am very much mistaken.
Mrs. Hentig says now that
she is going to compel the
captain to go on a leave-
But you know, my precious
wifie, how much attention
he pays to her compulsion.
He certainly ought to have
money enough to take him
on a leave, for since the ad-
-vent of our new C.O., the
season of gambling has been
a very brisk one, & cap't. Hen-
-tig generally wins when he plays.
(Page 17.) Didn't I tell you, my
precious wifie, that if Mrs.
Hentig expected too much of
her new soldier Cook, Mr “Speck”,
that she would be disappointed.
Well, it was just as I said-
The Captain told “Speck” to have
a pair of chickens roasted
for dinner, & Mrs. Harrison
told me of their appearance,
when they were brought in-
necks &“pope's noses” gone!
wings cut close off to their
bodies, and then both chickens
perfectly & neatly skinned!
She says that they looked
actually so funny, that none
of them knew what they
were, & that when they did
find out, they nearly split
their sides laughing! The legs,
by the way, were left on & were
sticking straight up in the
air, as a mild protest on
on the part of the birds, for
their shabby treatment by
Señor “Speck”! Salt on pies,
and Sugar in Soup are pret-
ty difficult ideas to surpass,
but I think Mr “Speck” will
get up something more en-
-tertaining than either of those,
if he is only given time and
opportunity- I have con-
gratulated the “Duchess” hear-
-tily upon her new “Menial-”
I have advised her to ap-
-point “Tom” Hentig as “first
assistant”! Hesche, enchaw!
Present my regards to Miss Lou
Woodward and tell her that Lt.
Mills, necklace and all, have ta-
-ken their departure for the
Southern part of the territory,
or else I would insist upon
his forwarding the ornament
at once. However, if allowable,
Congratulate her for me, on the
acquisition which she has
obtained in the shape of Señor
Don Vaughauero- Now, if you
think, my darling wifie, that
she would be angry, if you
you should tell her the above,
don't mention it for all the world.
I would like to be in Mur-
-freesboro, just to see how
gallant the young lad makes
himself, & the winsome glan-
-ces which the lassie gives
in return! “I want to know”!
Please enlighten my stupidity,
beauty, dear, by telling me
who Miss Mollie Day was,
and also the “noble” “gent” whom
she caught on the wing- as
it were- I really can't “locate”
her, as C. Reed, would say-
By the way, has the festive
Don Grimes lead any maiden
coy to the altar yet? I
really have forgotten whether
you told me that he was
married or not- and Miss
Nellie is no longer the reighning raining
(blast the spelling!) beauty? Ah!
I am afraid, she has rejected
one too many! But my little
“Nemps” wan't caught napping
that way, was she, lovie? I
tell you, the first beau that
came along, she “knabbed” him,
and a fine boy with him!
“Boodigs, enchaw”! She wasn't
going to “waste her sweetness
on the desert air”- although
she has had a pretty good
opportunity of doing so since.
(Colorado desert, lovie,- “Boodigs”)
But I can't write any more,
this time - Be a good, sweet, true,
loving little wifie & take good
care of papa's darling boy- Kisses
for Mama & son & bushels of love.
Best love to all homefolks, and re-
gards to all inquiring friends-
div1.closer:
Ever,
lovie, your own fond & devoted “hub”. Walter.
